title_sort: john m. rogers to walt whitman, 25 april 1875
title: John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 25 April 1875
text: New BritainApril 25 1875Dear Father & FriendYour letter came to hand the first of this week and I was glad to hear from you but very sorry to hear of your loss of health & bereavement this liaves[leaves] me and family all well, my little Boy is growing very fast and is getting as fat as he can be Worke[Work] is very dul[dull] here I have only about two days work in a week and the wages are small I do not everage[average] two dollars a day when I work I am working on locks I do not like the place here and shall get away from here as soon as I can How Is work there I can work at most any thing that comes along I should like very much to see you and if every thing goes well I may come on to see you this summer I got a little behind through the winter and have not quite caught up yet I have got a little Buisness[Business] out side of my work which I do Evenings I am connected with Sovererns[Sovereigns] of Industry I Sell Butter & Sigars[Cigars] and that helps me a great deal so that I manadge[manage] to get along And I think by the first of June I shall be all square here We deal with a firm in Philadefia[Philadelphia] Clothes Bennett & CoCompany Tower Hall I think it is in Market St.Street there is a Mr Walters with them and he is coming on here soon to take Orders and Measament[Measurement] for the Soverns[Sovereigns] Do you remember meeting a young Lady with me at the connir[corner] of Fulton and Court StsStreets once that is my wife she remembers you well so good by[bye] for this time I will try to write oftener in future we all send lovefrom your affecinat[affectionate] son &cJ. M. Rogers.John M. RogersNew Britain ConnConnecticutApril 26. '75 John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 25 April 1875
